articles.headline: Lofty Pledge to Cut Emissions Comes With Caveat in Norway
articles.snippet: Critics say Norway’s plan to become “carbon neutral” relies too heavily on sleight-of-hand accounting and donations to foreign environmental projects.
articles.abstract: Critics say Norway’s plan to become “carbon neutral” relies too heavily on sleight-of-hand accounting and donations to foreign environmental projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO  Last year, as United Nations scientists were warning of the perils of man-made climate change, this small country of fjords and factories reacted with an extraordinary pledge: by 2050 Norway would be “carbon neutral,” generating no net greenhouse gases into the air.

articles.headline: First a Tense Talk With Clinton, Then Richardson Backs Obama
articles.snippet: Gov. Bill Richardson urged Democrats to unite behind Senator Barack Obama to move the nation beyond its racial and partisan divide.
articles.abstract: Gov. Bill Richardson urged Democrats to unite behind Senator Barack Obama to move the nation beyond its racial and partisan divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  “I talked to Senator Clinton last night,” Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico said on Friday, describing the tense telephone call in which he informed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that, despite two months of personal entreaties by her and her husband, he would be endorsing Senator Barack Obama for president.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: New Focus of Inquiry Into Bribes: Doctors
articles.snippet: A long-running federal investigation into the orthopedic device industry’s suspected kickback payments to hip and knee surgeons now has the doctors in the spotlight.
articles.abstract: A long-running federal investigation into the orthopedic device industry’s suspected kickback payments to hip and knee surgeons now has the doctors in the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: A long-running federal investigation into the orthopedic device industry’s suspected kickback payments to hip and knee surgeons now has the doctors in the spotlight.

articles.headline: Pakistan to Talk With Militants, New Leaders Say
articles.snippet: American officials fear a softening stance just as President Pervez Musharraf has given the U.S. a freer hand to strike at militants.
articles.abstract: American officials fear a softening stance just as President Pervez Musharraf has given the U.S. a freer hand to strike at militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Faced with a sharp escalation of suicide bombings in urban areas, the leaders of Pakistan’s new coalition government say they will negotiate with the militants believed to be orchestrating the attacks, and will use military force only as a last resort.

articles.headline: Debt-Gorged British Start to Worry That the Party Is Ending
articles.snippet: For most of the last decade, consumers in Britain went on a debt-financed spending spree, racking up a record £1.4 trillion in debt ($2.8 trillion) — more than the country’s gross domestic product.
articles.abstract: For most of the last decade, consumers in Britain went on a debt-financed spending spree, racking up a record £1.4 trillion in debt ($2.8 trillion) — more than the country’s gross domestic product.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  At one point, Alexis Hall had more than 50 pairs of designer shoes and handbags. It never occurred to the 39-year-old media relations executive from Glasgow that her £31,500 in debt ($63,000) would be a problem.

articles.headline: Thinking Green While Sifting Through the Sand
articles.snippet: On a recent weekend on his private Caribbean island, Sir Richard Branson and several high-powered visitors gathered to figure out what to do about global warming.
articles.abstract: On a recent weekend on his private Caribbean island, Sir Richard Branson and several high-powered visitors gathered to figure out what to do about global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: NECKER ISLAND, British Virgin Islands  Richard Branson was lounging under the starry midnight sky on this palm-dappled speck of an island recently when he popped a sobering question.

articles.headline: Passport Files of 3 Candidates Were Pried Into
articles.snippet: Files containing personal information about Barack Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain were breached, the State Department said.
articles.abstract: Files containing personal information about Barack Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain were breached, the State Department said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The State Department, in an embarrassing revelation, said Friday that it was investigating several episodes in which an employee and several contract workers peered into the passport files of all three presidential contenders.

articles.headline: Corner of Finance Where Women Are Climbing
articles.snippet: Women now manage 10 of the 50 largest university endowments and private foundations, compared with 4 a decade ago, and oversee a combined $60.6 billion.
articles.abstract: Women now manage 10 of the 50 largest university endowments and private foundations, compared with 4 a decade ago, and oversee a combined $60.6 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any growth in the ranks of women at the highest reaches of corporate America tends to be measured in small increments, particularly in the so-called C-suite jobs like chief executive and chief operating officer.

articles.headline: Resist the Impulse to Panic Over Finances
articles.snippet: Short of putting our heads in the sand and hoping all the bad financial news passes, what should we do with our own finances?
articles.abstract: Short of putting our heads in the sand and hoping all the bad financial news passes, what should we do with our own finances?
articles.lead_paragraph: A major investment bank has collapsed, and the Fed is cutting interest rates to stave off a recession that we may already be in. More and more people seem to be having trouble making their mortgage payments, and credit card delinquencies are up.

articles.headline: What Created This Monster?
articles.snippet: Executives, regulators and politicians are scrambling to figure out just what created the credit crisis and how it can be fixed.
articles.abstract: Executives, regulators and politicians are scrambling to figure out just what created the credit crisis and how it can be fixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE Noah building his ark as thunderheads gathered, Bill Gross has spent the last two years anticipating the flood that swamped Bear Stearns about 10 days ago. As manager of the world’s biggest bond fund and custodian of nearly a trillion dollars in assets, Mr. Gross amassed a cash hoard of $50 billion in case trading partners suddenly demanded payment from his firm, Pimco.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Even at Megastores, Hagglers Find No Price Is Set in Stone
articles.snippet: A bargaining culture once confined to car showrooms and jewelry stores is taking root in some major chains.
articles.abstract: A bargaining culture once confined to car showrooms and jewelry stores is taking root in some major chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Shoppers are discovering an upside to the down economy. They are getting price breaks by reviving an age-old retail strategy: haggling.

articles.headline: McCain Offers Soothing Tones in Trip Abroad
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain faces the challenge of improving America’s image abroad despite the unpopularity of the Iraq war — which he strongly supports.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain faces the challenge of improving America’s image abroad despite the unpopularity of the Iraq war — which he strongly supports.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Senator John McCain’s trip abroad this week  which took him from the Middle East to No. 10 Downing Street to the Élysée Palace here  was more than just a Congressional fact-finding trip, or even a candidate’s attempt to appear statesmanlike.

articles.headline: Haiti’s Poverty Stirs Nostalgia for Old Ghosts
articles.snippet: With change slow to come to Haiti, many people speak longingly of the security that existed in the country’s dictatorial past.
articles.abstract: With change slow to come to Haiti, many people speak longingly of the security that existed in the country’s dictatorial past.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The imported granite was smashed. The giant cupola was toppled. The grave of François Duvalier, the longtime dictator, is a wreck, much like the country he left behind.

articles.headline: At Cineplexes, Sports, Opera, Maybe a Movie
articles.snippet: Movie theaters are not just for movies anymore. As ticket sales slow, theaters are turning to the Mets and the Met.
articles.abstract: Movie theaters are not just for movies anymore. As ticket sales slow, theaters are turning to the Mets and the Met.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie theaters are not just for movies anymore.

articles.headline: In the Fed’s Cross Hairs: Exotic Game
articles.snippet: The Fed’s actions in the JPMorgan-Bear Stearns marriage may take some air out of the enormous bubble in credit insurance.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s actions in the JPMorgan-Bear Stearns marriage may take some air out of the enormous bubble in credit insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the week or so since the Federal Reserve Bank of New York pushed Bear Stearns into the arms of JPMorgan Chase, there has been much buzz about why the deal went down precisely as it did.

articles.headline: Obama’s Talk Fuels Easter Sermons
articles.snippet: Inspired by Senator Barack Obama’s speech, some religious leaders plan to interweave race and resurrection.
articles.abstract: Inspired by Senator Barack Obama’s speech, some religious leaders plan to interweave race and resurrection.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Easter Sunday, the holiest day of the Christian calendar, many pastors will start their sermons about the Resurrection of Jesus and weave in a pointed message about racism and bigotry, and the need to rise above them.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Neela Banerjee

articles.headline: Split Is Forming Over Regulation of Wall Street
articles.snippet: Congress and the Bush administration strongly disagree about whether the pendulum should swing back to tighter control.
articles.abstract: Congress and the Bush administration strongly disagree about whether the pendulum should swing back to tighter control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the Bush administration struggle to contain the housing and credit crises  and prevent more Wall Street firms from collapsing as Bear Stearns did  a split is forming over how to strengthen oversight of financial institutions after decades of deregulation.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Newspapers’ New Owners Turn Grim
articles.snippet: Smart businesspeople who appointed themselves as life savers for newspapers are finding it more difficult than they thought to keep their businesses afloat.
articles.abstract: Smart businesspeople who appointed themselves as life savers for newspapers are finding it more difficult than they thought to keep their businesses afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Critics of newspapers say that part of the problem is that the industry has lost its ability to surprise. Tell that to the guys who have just bought in.

articles.headline: A Murdoch Sets Her Own Course in TV
articles.snippet: About two-thirds of the income from Elisabeth Murdoch’s burgeoning television empire is expected to come from the United States.
articles.abstract: About two-thirds of the income from Elisabeth Murdoch’s burgeoning television empire is expected to come from the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: One morning last May, Elisabeth Murdoch was leaving a Starbucks in London when her cellphone rang. Her good friend Ben Silverman was calling from Los Angeles to say he could no longer discuss selling her his independent television production company, Reveille.

articles.headline: A Boy the Bullies Love to Beat Up, Repeatedly
articles.snippet: The many incidents of bullying against Billy Wolfe seem to blur together into one protracted assault.
articles.abstract: The many incidents of bullying against Billy Wolfe seem to blur together into one protracted assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.

articles.headline: As Tibet Erupted, China Security Forces Wavered
articles.snippet: Witnesses say that for almost 24 hours after Lhasa erupted, police officers were often nowhere to be found.
articles.abstract: Witnesses say that for almost 24 hours after Lhasa erupted, police officers were often nowhere to be found.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  In the chaotic hours after Lhasa erupted March 14, Tibetans rampaged through the city’s old quarter, waving steel scabbards and burning or looting Chinese shops. Clothes, souvenirs and other tourist trinkets were dumped outside and set afire as thick gray smoke darkened the midday sky. Tibetan fury, uncorked, boiled over.

articles.headline: A New Tool From Google Alarms Sites
articles.snippet: Google’s new search-within-search feature has sparked fears from publishers and retailers that users will be siphoned away through ad sales to competitors.
articles.abstract: Google’s new search-within-search feature has sparked fears from publishers and retailers that users will be siphoned away through ad sales to competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retailers and publishers have fought hard to work their way up in the ranking of Google’s search results and refine the search features of their own Web sites to help users once they arrive. Now, Google is taking a greater role in helping users search within particular sites. And some of the same retailers and publishers are not happy about it.

articles.headline: JPMorgan in Negotiations to Raise Bear Stearns Bid
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase was in talks for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns in an effort to pacify Bear shareholders, according to people involved in the discussions.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase was in talks for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns in an effort to pacify Bear shareholders, according to people involved in the discussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase was in talks on Sunday night for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders, according to people involved in the negotiations.

articles.headline: Peacekeeping in Darfur Hits More Obstacles
articles.snippet: Bureaucracy, stonewalling by Sudan and a lack of troops and supplies have threatened the mission as it begins.
articles.abstract: Bureaucracy, stonewalling by Sudan and a lack of troops and supplies have threatened the mission as it begins.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU SUROUJ, Sudan  As Darfur smolders in the aftermath of a new government offensive, a long-sought peacekeeping force, expected to be the world’s largest, is in danger of failing even as it begins its mission because of bureaucratic delays, stonewalling by Sudan’s government and reluctance from troop-contributing countries to send peacekeeping forces into an active conflict.

articles.headline: With Economy Tied to Wall St., New York Braces for Job Cuts
articles.snippet: The finance industry was responsible for nearly a third of all wages earned in New York City in 2007, the highest in modern times.
articles.abstract: The finance industry was responsible for nearly a third of all wages earned in New York City in 2007, the highest in modern times.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York is accustomed to job losses on Wall Street. They come with just about every economic slump, and their impact is felt throughout the city.

articles.headline: Where Wall Street’s Caviar Set Still Thrives
articles.snippet: There may be panic on Wall Street, but Doubledown Media, publisher of magazines for the wealthy, says its business and readers are largely immune to the problems.
articles.abstract: There may be panic on Wall Street, but Doubledown Media, publisher of magazines for the wealthy, says its business and readers are largely immune to the problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifteen thousand jobs lost in the financial sector since the fall. Recession. Panic on Wall Street. Crisis in the housing market. Bear Stearns sold at $2 a share.

articles.headline: The War Endures, but Where’s the Media?
articles.snippet: Iraq coverage by major American news sources has dropped to about one-fifth of what it was last summer, according to a survey.
articles.abstract: Iraq coverage by major American news sources has dropped to about one-fifth of what it was last summer, according to a survey.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years later, the United States remains at war in Iraq, but there are days when it would be hard to tell from a quick look at television news, newspapers and the Internet.
